title: Pilidiostigma glabrum
text:
Pilidiostigma glabrum, the plum myrtle, is a small tree or <a href="shrub">shrub</a> native to the <a href="rainforest">rainforest</a>s of eastern Australia. Commonly seen in disturbed sites from near <a href="Port%20Macquarie">Port Macquarie</a> in the south to <a href="Fraser%20Island">Fraser Island</a> in the north. 
Leaves and floral parts are hairless. Leaves opposite on the stem, 2 to 10 cm long, 1 to 3 cm wide, oil glands, very small. A narrow leaf form is found near Crystal Creek, in northern New South Wales. Small branches coloured purple/brown.
White or pink flowers grow relatively large, 2 cm across, appearing from April to November. Fruit are a purplish black pear shaped <a href="Berry%20%28botany%29">berry</a>, up to 13 mm in diameter, with four to eight kidney shaped seeds. Seeds germinate easily from 7 to 28 days. Cuttings are slow to strike roots.
